Treatment for pus cells in semen is not.context: Pus cells in the semen - and how to make sense of the report One of the common findings in a semen analysis report is the presence of a few pus cells per high power field ( pus cells/ hpf). The technical word for this is called pyospermia or leucocytospermia. Pus cells are WBCs - white blood cells, and less than 5 pus cells / hpf is considered to be normal, but this finding is often highlighted in red as being abnormal, and this often causes both the doctor as well as the patient to worry.The WHO Manual states that less than 1 million WBC per ml is normal, but the majority of labs never bother to measure the actual concentration of the WBCs - the technician simply eyeballs the sample and estimate this in terms of rounds cells seen in each visual field when scanning the samples through the microscope. Patients are worried that these pus cells suggest they are suffering from an occult infection - perhaps a sexually transmitted disease ( STD) which they knew they had acquired in the past, and they are worried that they can transmit this to their wife.They are also worried that this hidden infection can kill their sperm, or reduce their ability to fertilise the eggs.Doctors are also happy to "treat" this abnormality by putting the man on antibiotics, because these are so easy to prescribe, and because this seems to be a logical thing to do. They hope these antibiotics will kill the bugs causing the infection, and this will boost the man's fertility. The reason this is flawed logic is because the "pus cells" seen on a semen analysis report when checked through the microscope are simply round cells, which are misinterpreted as being pus cells .When examining the semen under the microscope, it's very easy to identify sperm because they have a tail and are moving rapidly. However, seminal fluid also contains many other cells, including the epithelial cells which line the male reproductive tract, as well as sperm precursor cells. Most laboratory technicians will report every round cell they see as a pus cell or a WBC , but most of these are actually immature sperm precursors, called spermatocytes or spermatogonia , which look exactly the same. However, most labs don't have the special stains needed to identify whether this round cell is a WBC or not , which is why they will report all the round cells as pus cells !The doctor then promptly prescribes antibiotics, but this is a complete waste, because there was no infection in the first place, and antibiotics will not cause the sperm precursor cells to go away !Patients end up wasting a lot of time and money on taking antibiotics . Some doctors will also send the semen sample to the microbiology lab to try to culture the microbe causing the purported infection.

What type of startups are you interested in?
I am interested in early-stage startups with paying customers and a pre-money valuation of about Rs 10-50  crores. [Read More](https://www.indianangel.in/i-would-like-entrepreneurs-to-suggest-names-of-startups-i/7145/)

Are we the right investors for you? Finally, our sweet spot is the angel stage. We like to come in early and work closely with entrepreneurs who are building their ventures. Our ticket size is anywhere between Rs 50 lacs to 150 lacs depending on the age, maturity of business model, and our comfort level with the entrepreneurs. At the same time, we also provide the entrepreneur with an unwavering support in their quest to grow their venture, and at times also participate in bridge and follow on rounds to show solidarity. Because we like to come in early and bet on yet unproven business models untested at scale, we prefer to have sizeable skin in the game for it to make it worth our while. While we do not like to negotiate with entrepreneurs on the valuation of their ventures and want them to propose the valuation they are comfortable with, we prefer pre-money valuations between Rs 5 cr to 15 cr above which it has to be either an extremely superior business model or very strong credibility of the entrepreneur for us to consider our participation. And until it is time for the startups to learn from professional venture capitalists, we will be happy to handhold them in all walks of life.We are always looking for exciting new startups to invest in, and bright entrepreneurs to learn from. If your startup fits our investment thesis as mentioned above, we would love to hear from you.

Most investors prefer funding new startups , in the hope ... Most investors prefer funding new startups , in the hope that they will be able to find the next unicorn . Startups which have been plodding along for many years find it very hard to attract investors , because they haven't been able to show exponential growth during their journey .  However, these are actually a better bet for angel investors , because they are proven to be antifragile ! The founders have learned a lot about their domain , and have a reputation to protect. They have existing customers , and can tap into their network to grow, once they are funded.  Also, the competition for investing in these start-ups is much less , which means the pre money valuation is also much more reasonable ! ,

Yes, you can include supporting informat.context:
Can you use any portfolio for your appraisal?
The format of the portfolio of supporting information is not prescribed by the GMC, so having an electronic portfolio is not a requirement for revalidation. 
Content from: Mythbusters@RCGP



Key Insights:

Introduction: Professor Rayan Kazi from Medical Appraisals UK presents a video addressing a common query regarding the use of a portfolio of choice for appraisal, especially targeted at doctors seeking self-appraisal.

Source of Content: The content of the video is sourced from Mythbusters at the Royal College of General Practitioners (rcgp), indicating reliance on reputable sources within the medical community.

Portfolio Format: The format of the portfolio of supporting information is not prescribed by the General Medical Council (GMC). An electronic portfolio is not mandatory for revalidation, offering flexibility in the choice of format.

Recommendations for Portfolio: It is recommended that the portfolio includes all core elements required by the GMC. The suggested format is professionally presented, typed for legibility, and capable of electronic transmission.

Confidentiality of Supporting Information: Certain supporting information, such as original complaint letters and handwritten complement cards, is recommended to be kept in paper form and shared privately with the appraiser to maintain confidentiality. These can then be referenced anonymously in the summary.

Medical Appraisal Guide Model Form: The Medical Appraisal Guide model form by NHS England is highlighted as a free interactive PDF available from the NHS England website. It serves as a template for all other toolkit providers, with its use not restricted to England alone.

National Platforms in Scotland and Wales: In Scotland and Wales, national appraisal and revalidation platforms (SOAR in Scotland and MARS in Wales) are mentioned, providing a standardized approach for all doctors.

Responsibility of Responsible Officers (ROs): Responsible officers may express a preference among available options, and doctors are encouraged to check with designated body requirements and variations. Special arrangements might be needed for accessibility issues related to a protected characteristic.

Moving to a New Area: When relocating to a new area in the UK, it is advised to check if a preferred local choice of the portfolio is being used.

Portfolio Accessibility: Doctors are reminded that the portfolio, containing all GMC-required supporting information, should be available to the responsible officer potentially at short notice.

Can supporting information from work overseas be included in a medical appraisal?
This video explains if supporting information from work overseas can be included in the appraisal portfolio of doctors.

From: RCGP-Revalidation-Mythbusters-2016.pdf

Designated body At Medical Appraisals, we offer a medical appraisal service for doctors.   Our goal is to provide a smooth and efficient appraisal process tailored to your needs.  We can offer some very valuable advice as regards your designated body options at the time of the appraisal meeting.   Is there a specific aspect of our services you would like more information about?

Medical Appraisal Requirements For Overseas/ Non-UK Doctors
The GMC requirement is that your appraisal and revalidation portfolio should include supporting information about every part of your scope of practice that requires a UK licence. As the above makes clear, your RO has the discretion to consider supporting information from other settings in making their revalidation recommendation.
Even in UK practice, you may attend CPD events overseas. It is appropriate to check that the content of such an event is applicable to your scope of practice rather than assuming that it will be acceptable. We recommend that you discuss any proposal to include any such additional supporting information with your RO in advance of your revalidation recommendation date. It is likely that clinical work overseas will have a significant overlap with clinical work in the UK. It may well be appropriate to include supporting information relating to work overseas when it demonstrates the quality of your reflective practice.
If you are unsure, use your appraisal as an opportunity to reflect on what is appropriate and proportionate with your appraiser, and then agree it with your RO before your revalidation recommendation is due. Content from: Mythbusters@RCGP
 
*Key Insights:*
*Common Query Addressed:*
- The video addresses a common question among appraisees: whether they can include supporting information from non-UK sources in their appraisal.
*Source of Content:*
- The information in the video is derived from Mythbusters at the Royal College of General Practitioners (RCGP), emphasizing the reliability of the content.
*Practice Settings Abroad:*
- Doctors practicing overseas, where a UK license is not required, have the discretion to include supporting information from these settings. It's at their judgment whether such information is relevant to their scope of practice.
*GMC Requirements:*
- The General Medical Council (GMC) requires that the appraisal and revalidation portfolio include supporting information for every aspect of the scope of practice requiring a UK license.
*Discretion in Considering Information:*
- The Responsible Officer (RO) has the discretion to consider supporting information from non-UK settings when making revalidation recommendations. However, it is crucial to ensure that the content is applicable to the scope of practice.
*Communication with RO:*
- Doctors are encouraged to discuss any proposal to include additional supporting information from non-UK settings with their Responsible Officer before the revalidation recommendation date.
*Overlap with UK Clinical Work:*
- Clinical work overseas may overlap significantly with work in the UK. In such cases, it might be appropriate to include supporting information related to overseas work, particularly if it demonstrates the quality of reflective practice.
*Reflective Practice:*
- The video suggests using the appraisal as an opportunity to reflect on what supporting information is appropriate and proportionate. Discussion with the appraiser and agreement with the Responsible Officer is recommended before the revalidation recommendation.

Certificates of attendance at CPD events.context:
Are Certificates Of Attendance At CPD Events Important For A Medical Appraisal?
Certificates of attendance may prove attendance at an event, but they are not proof of learning or development. They say nothing about what has been learned, or any changes you have made as a result.
A reflective note, no matter how brief, is far more valuable evidence of reflective practice and continuing professional development than a certificate. A lot of valuable learning takes place in ways that do not
generate a certificate, such as personal reading and professional conversations with colleagues. We encourage you to think about how and what you have learnt, defining one CPD credit as one hour of learning activity as demonstrated by a reflective note on the lessons learned and any changes made as a result.
You should not waste time scanning certificates of attendance into your portfolio of supporting information, unless keeping formal proof of attendance on courses that are organisational requirements may be useful
to you, such as Basic Life Support and Safeguarding. Appraisers should not be asking to see certificates of attendance; they should be asking what your most important new learning has been over the past year and what difference it has made to your practice.
Many CPD facilitators now provide certificates that include a structured format or template for you to write appropriate reflective notes about learning and planned changes that will have an impact on your practice.
It is reasonable to scan these rather than rewriting the reflective note elsewhere. You can also choose not to complete the certificate at all if the reflective note is captured elsewhere in a learning log or electronic
toolkit. Your aim should be to avoid duplication of effort.

key insight : from the provided information on Medical Appraisals in the UK is that certificates of attendance at Continuing Professional Development (CPD) events are considered proof of attendance but not sufficient evidence of learning or development. The video emphasizes that merely attending an event does not convey what has been learned or the impact on one's practice. Instead, the focus is on the importance of reflective practice, encouraging appraisers to provide reflective notes as more valuable evidence of CPD.

The video suggests that a brief reflective note is far more valuable than a certificate, as it demonstrates the individual's understanding of what was learned and any changes made as a result. The emphasis is on capturing the essence of the learning experience and its application to professional development. The content discourages the unnecessary inclusion of certificates of attendance in the appraisal portfolio unless required by the organization for specific courses.

Appraisers are advised to ask about the most significant new learning over the past year and its impact on practice, shifting the focus from proof of attendance to the meaningful outcomes of the learning process. Many CPD facilitators now provide certificates with structured formats or templates for writing reflective notes, making it reasonable to include these in the portfolio.

I can help you with your upcoming medica.context:
My Responsible Officer Forgot To Remind Me That My Annual Medical Appraisal Is Due!
GMC statutory guidance states that to maintain your licence to practise, you must ensure that you have an annual medical appraisal and demonstrate your continued competence across your whole scope of practice. Your responsible officer (RO) has a duty to ensure that there is a suitable, quality-assured, appraisal process for you to participate in. The GMC requires you to engage with your annual appraisal process on an ongoing basis. It is your responsibility to ensure that you have an appraisal.
Content from: Mythbusters@RCGP

*Key Insights:*
*Responsibility for Annual Appraisal:*
- The video addresses the question of whether it is the responsibility of individual doctors or their Responsible Officer (RO) to ensure timely annual appraisals.
*GMC Statutory Guidance:*
- The GMC statutory guidance emphasizes that doctors must ensure they undergo an annual medical appraisal and demonstrate continued competence across their entire scope of practice.
*RO's Duty:*
- The RO has a duty to ensure there is a suitable, quality-assured appraisal process available for doctors. However, the responsibility to engage with the annual appraisal process lies with the individual doctor.
*Ongoing Engagement:*
- Ongoing engagement with the annual appraisal process is highlighted as the doctor's responsibility, emphasizing the need for proactive participation.
*Organizing Appraisal Without RO:*
- In cases where doctors do not have an RO or a suitable person, they are encouraged to organize an annual appraisal that meets GMC criteria for revalidation.
*Designated Body's Appraisal Policy:*
- For those working in designated bodies with organizational appraisal policies, doctors are urged to understand the policies and know how to access their annual appraisal.
*Proactive Approach:*
- Doctors are advised to be proactive in ensuring they have a meaningful annual appraisal that aligns with their professional and developmental needs within their specific working context.
*Seeking Advice:*
- If a doctor believes they should be offered an appraisal and are not, they are encouraged to seek advice from their designated body and take proactive steps to be included in the appraisal process.
*Role in Highlighting Errors:*
- Doctors are regarded as best placed to highlight administrative errors in the appraisal process, emphasizing their active role in the process.

Having an appraisal with Medical Apprais.context:
Will The Medical Appraiser Decide About My GMC Revalidation Recommendation?
This video clears the commonly held misconception that appraisers decide the revalidation recommendation for doctors.

key insight:

Appraiser's Role: The primary role of the appraiser is to facilitate the doctor's reflection, provide support, stimulate development, and help present an appropriate portfolio of supporting information for the Responsible Officer (RO) to consider.
Facilitating Documentation: Appraisers play a crucial role in producing a comprehensive summary of the evidence supplied by the doctor, representing them to the RO. This involves ensuring that the documentation complies with the requirements for revalidation.
RO's Statutory Responsibility: The RO holds the statutory responsibility for making the revalidation recommendation to the General Medical Council (GMC). The RO's decision is based on factors such as the doctor's engagement in annual appraisal, the quality of the supporting information portfolio, and any outstanding concerns within the scope of work.
GMC Revalidation Decision: Ultimately, the GMC makes the revalidation decision, determining whether to continue the doctor's license to practice.
Appraiser as a Resource: While the appraiser does not make the revalidation decision, they are a valuable resource in helping doctors improve the quality of documentation, especially in areas such as the quality of reflection and the relevance of supporting information across the entire scope of work.
Importance of Engagement: The video highlights that insufficient engagement is often related to the quality of reflection and the relevance of supporting information across the entire scope of work.
Professional Development Planning: Appraisers can support doctors in planning their professional development in a way that enhances the quality of their professional work.

Who Is My Designated Body For Medical Appraisal?
According to The Medical Profession (Responsible Officers) Regulations 2010(link is external), designated bodies are: 
Organisations that provide healthcare
Organisations that set standards and policy for the delivery of healthcare
Some specialist organisations that employ or contract with doctors. 
Content from: https://www.rcpe.ac.uk/careers-training/how-do-i-confirm-my-prescribed-connection-designated-body-and-responsible-officer



key insights:

Designated Bodies Definition: Designated bodies are organizations that play a crucial role in healthcare. They can be healthcare providers, organizations setting healthcare standards and policies, or certain specialized organizations employing or contracting with doctors.

Responsible Officer (RO): The majority of designated bodies have a Responsible Officer (RO) in place. RO is an important figure in the revalidation process and is responsible for overseeing the appraisal and revalidation of doctors within the designated body.

Prescribed Connection: Each doctor can have only one prescribed connection to a designated body. In most cases, this prescribed connection is where the doctor performs the majority of their clinical work.

Identifying Designated Body and RO: Doctors can identify their designated body and RO by setting up a GMC (General Medical Council) online account. The GMC website provides a full list of designated bodies, and doctors can use an online tool under the revalidation section to confirm their designated body.

Employment and Prescribed Link: If a doctor is employed by an NHS organization but works for another organization through contracted sessions, their prescribed link will be to the NHS organization and its RO, regardless of the time spent outside.

Confirmation of Designated Body: Once the designated body is confirmed, the RO should assist the doctor in identifying a suitable appraiser for the revalidation process.

No Designated Body Connection: If a doctor doesn't have a connection to any organization classified as a designated body, they should inform the GMC about their circumstances using their online account.

Finding a Responsible Officer: In cases where a responsible officer cannot be found, it may be possible to identify a suitable person. The GMC website provides more information and guidance on this.

Designated bodies are typically organiza.context:
All you need to know about a 'designated body'
The revalidation of doctors is a crucial aspect of medical regulation aimed at ensuring ongoing professional development, accountability, and quality assurance in healthcare delivery. Designated bodies play a pivotal role in facilitating the revalidation process, overseeing the appraisal and performance assessment of doctors, and upholding standards of excellence in medical practice. 

In the United Kingdom, according to the Responsible Officer Regulations, a designated body is typically an organization or institution that employs or contracts with doctors and is responsible for the following:

1. Appointing responsible officers: Designated bodies appoint responsible officers who oversee the appraisal and revalidation of doctors within their organization.

2. Supporting appraisal and revalidation: Designated bodies provide support and resources for doctors to undergo appraisal, which involves regular assessment of their performance and professional development. They also facilitate the revalidation process, which is the periodic evaluation of doctors' fitness to practice.

3. Ensuring compliance with regulatory requirements: Designated bodies ensure that doctors meet the necessary standards of competence, conduct, and professionalism required by regulatory authorities such as the General Medical Council (GMC) in the UK.

Designated bodies in the context of Responsible Officer Regulations are typically healthcare organizations, including hospitals, general practitioner (GP) practices, and other healthcare institutions where doctors work. These bodies play a crucial role in maintaining the quality and safety of medical care by overseeing the appraisal and revalidation of doctors and ensuring compliance with regulatory standards.

Designated Bodies Definition: Designated bodies are organizations that play a crucial role in healthcare. They can be healthcare providers, organizations setting healthcare standards and policies, or certain specialized organizations employing or contracting with doctors.

Responsible Officer (RO): The majority of designated bodies have a Responsible Officer (RO) in place. RO is an important figure in the revalidation process and is responsible for overseeing the appraisal and revalidation of doctors within the designated body.

Prescribed Connection: Each doctor can have only one prescribed connection to a designated body. In most cases, this prescribed connection is where the doctor performs the majority of their clinical work.

Identifying Designated Body and RO: Doctors can identify their designated body and RO by setting up a GMC (General Medical Council) online account. The GMC website provides a full list of designated bodies, and doctors can use an online tool under the revalidation section to confirm their designated body.

Employment and Prescribed Link: If a doctor is employed by an NHS organization but works for another organization through contracted sessions, their prescribed link will be to the NHS organization and its RO, regardless of the time spent outside.

Confirmation of Designated Body: Once the designated body is confirmed, the RO should assist the doctor in identifying a suitable appraiser for the revalidation process.

No Designated Body Connection: If a doctor doesn't have a connection to any organization classified as a designated body, they should inform the GMC about their circumstances using their online account.

Finding a Responsible Officer: In cases where a responsible officer cannot be found, it may be possible to identify a suitable person. The GMC website provides more information and guidance on this.

All you need to know about a 'designated body'
The revalidation of doctors is a crucial aspect of medical regulation aimed at ensuring ongoing professional development, accountability, and quality assurance in healthcare delivery. Designated bodies play a pivotal role in facilitating the revalidation process, overseeing the appraisal and performance assessment of doctors, and upholding standards of excellence in medical practice. 

In the United Kingdom, according to the Responsible Officer Regulations, a designated body is typically an organization or institution that employs or contracts with doctors and is responsible for the following:

1. Appointing responsible officers: Designated bodies appoint responsible officers who oversee the appraisal and revalidation of doctors within their organization.

2. Supporting appraisal and revalidation: Designated bodies provide support and resources for doctors to undergo appraisal, which involves regular assessment of their performance and professional development. They also facilitate the revalidation process, which is the periodic evaluation of doctors' fitness to practice.

3. Ensuring compliance with regulatory requirements: Designated bodies ensure that doctors meet the necessary standards of competence, conduct, and professionalism required by regulatory authorities such as the General Medical Council (GMC) in the UK.

Designated bodies in the context of Responsible Officer Regulations are typically healthcare organizations, including hospitals, general practitioner (GP) practices, and other healthcare institutions where doctors work. These bodies play a crucial role in maintaining the quality and safety of medical care by overseeing the appraisal and revalidation of doctors and ensuring compliance with regulatory standards.

Whose Responsibility Is To Ensure That I Have My Annual Medical Appraisal In Time?
Thank you for watching this video.
If you like the content here, please don't forget to like, share and subscribe!
GMC statutory guidance states that, to maintain your licence to practise, you must ensure that you have an annual medical appraisal and demonstrate your continued competence across your whole scope
of practice. Your responsible officer (RO) has a duty to ensure that there is a suitable, quality assured, appraisal process for you to participate in. The GMC requires you to engage with your annual appraisal process on an ongoing basis. Some doctors do not have an RO, or a Suitable Person, and still organise their own annual appraisal that meets the GMC criteria for a medical appraisal for revalidation.
If you work in a designated body with an organisational appraisal policy, it is your responsibility to understand what that means for you and how you should be accessing your annual appraisal. Your RO has a statutory responsibility for ensuring that the appraisal process is fit for purpose but you must play your part in engaging fully with the process.
We recommend that you are proactive in ensuring that you have an annual appraisal that is meaningful and meets your personal and professional development needs in the context in which you work. If your appraisal becomes disproportionately burdensome, we recommend that you speak to your appraiser and RO. They can support you and make recommendations.
If you think that you should be offered an appraisal and you are not, we recommend that you are proactive about seeking advice from your designated body and ensuring that you are included in the appraisal
process. Administrative errors do happen and you are best placed to highlight such omissions.

Prof. Rehan Kazi will schedule a video a.context: Who decides venue?  The appraisal meeting is online - over video

Who Decides On The Medical Appraisal Venue?
The appraisal venue should be mutually agreed between the appraisee and the appraiser and you should not feel pressured into meeting at a venue that does not suit you.



key insights:

Importance of Appraisal Environment: The video emphasizes that the most valuable appraisals occur in an environment that is private, confidential, and conducive to safe reflection and discussion. The choice of venue plays a significant role in the effectiveness of the appraisal process.

Mutual Agreement on Venue: The decision on the appraisal venue should be mutually agreed upon by both the appraisee (doctor being appraised) and the appraiser. There should be no pressure on the appraisee to meet in a venue that does not suit them.

Flexibility in Venue Choice: If the appraisee doesn't have a suitable professional venue or prefers to meet away from their workplace, it may be appropriate for them to travel to the appraiser or choose an alternate professional venue.

Designated Body's Policies: Some designated bodies may have specific arrangements outlined in their medical appraisal policy regarding venue choices. Appraisees should be aware of and adhere to any local requirements set by their designated bodies.

Requirements of a Professional Venue: Regardless of the venue chosen, it should meet certain criteria, including being private, free from interruptions, and equipped with necessary facilities like internet access.

Exceptional Circumstances: In exceptional circumstances, it might be appropriate to hold an appraisal meeting in an unusual venue, such as a home office. However, this decision should be agreed upon in writing with the appraisal leader before the meeting, and the agreement should be documented.

How to get a medical appraisal done?
This short and simple video highlights the steps and requirements of a medical appraisal as part of the GMC and NHS England appraisal requirements for doctors

Supporting Information For A Medical Appraisal
The GMC requires doctors to provide appropriate supporting information across the whole of their scope of practice that requires a licence to practise, not just clinical roles.
You must declare all parts of your scope of practice and, for each of them where appropriate, provide all
six types of supporting information over the revalidation cycle:
l CPD
l QIA
l significant events, if there are any
l patient feedback
l colleague feedback
l complaints and compliments, if there are any
We recommend that you keep the documentation of your supporting information reasonable and proportionate while ensuring that you have demonstrated that you are up-to-date and fit to practise in every scope of practice. Your appraiser will help you determine whether there are any gaps in your portfolio of supporting information and support you in working out how best to fill those gaps. Your responsible officer (RO) will tell you if your portfolio demonstrates sufficient engagement in reflective practice and provides the supporting information required by the GMC.
If you have any queries that your appraiser cannot resolve, we recommend that you seek early confirmation from your RO that what you are planning is going to be acceptable.
Content: Mythbusters@RCGP


Key insights:

Scope of Practice: The GMC (General Medical Council) requires doctors to provide appropriate supporting information across the entire scope of their practice that requires a license, not just clinical roles. This encompasses all aspects of a doctor's professional responsibilities.

Six Types of Supporting Information: For each part of the scope of practice, doctors need to provide all six types of supporting information over the revalidation cycle. These include CPD (Continuous Professional Development), quality improvement activities, significant events, patient feedback, colleague feedback, and information about any complaints and compliments.

Documentation Management: It is recommended to keep the documentation of supporting information reasonable and proportionate while ensuring that it demonstrates being up-to-date and fit to practice in every aspect of the scope of practice.

Appraiser's Role: The appraiser will assist in determining any gaps in the portfolio of supporting information and provide support in addressing those gaps. They play a crucial role in evaluating the completeness and appropriateness of the provided information.

Responsibility of Responsible Officer (RO): The Responsible Officer (RO) will assess whether the portfolio demonstrates sufficient engagement in reflective practice and contains the required supporting information according to GMC standards.

Communication with RO: If there are any queries that the appraiser cannot resolve, it is recommended to seek early confirmation from the Responsible Officer to ensure that the planned actions and documentation will be acceptable for revalidation.

What is the Cost for IVF?
A complete IVF cycle at our clinic costs about Rs 3,00,000 - and this is all-inclusive for all medical procedures. Medicines would cost about Rs  145000 more.

 Included services in our IVF cost:

    Ovarian stimulation monitoring

    Anesthesia for egg retrieval

    Egg retrieval procedure

    Fertilization and culture of the eggs

   All physician, IVF lab, and facility fees associated with in vitro fertilization

There is NO extra cost for doing ICSI or a blastocyst transfer !

Excluded services - not included in our IVF costs:

    Pre-IVF screening tests 

   Blood tests ( such as E2 levels)

    Embryo or sperm freezing or storage - these are optional services

The cost for freezing and storing embryos is Rs 70000 per year

The cost for thawing and transferring them is Rs 70000

We do NOT charge for followup consultations; or for reviewing test results.

The IVF process involves helping your ov.context:
What is the IVF process?
The IVF process involves helping your ovaries growmore eggs ( superovulation) , retrieving them through a minor surgical procedure ( egg retrieval) , fertilizing them with sperm in a lab dish and then transferring one ( or more) embryo backs into the uterus. It takes about 2- 3 weeks to complete an IVF cycle. For further information on this topic please visit
https://www.drmalpani.com/knowledge-center/ivf/ivf-treatment-plan

The 7 steps of IVF IVF seems to be an extremely complicated procedure, and sometimes IVF doctors take perverse pleasure in mystifying it, because they like showing off their expertise. This is why IVF patients are often completely confused about what to expect. Actually , it's very straightforward and logical, and if you understand this simple framework , you will be able to make sure your doctor's doing the right stuff for you. Remember that all we are doing in an IVF cycle is replicating what should have happened normally in the fallopian tubes - the only difference is that we are doing this in the test tube ! 1. First is the pre-IVF testing, or the workup. These are simple tests, to make sure whether IVF is the right treatment for you; and what kind of IVF you require ( for example, if this should be IVF or ICSI).(a). semen analysis for your husband ( to check his sperm count and motility); (b) blood tests for you for the following reproductive hormones - FSH ( follicle-stimulating hormone),LH ( luteinising hormone),PRL ( prolactin) , AMH ( anti-Mullerian hormone) and TSH ( thyroid stimulating hormone) on Day 3 of your cycle, ( to check the quality of your eggs). (c) A vaginal ultrasound scan on Day 10 or 11 which should check for a. ovarian volume; b. antral follicle count; c. uterus morphology; d. endometrial thickness and texture, to confirm your uterus is normal. If there is a problem, then this can be treated prior to starting IVF! 2. Second is the stage of superovulation , where the doctor gives you hormonal injections in order to help you to grow lots of eggs. The growth of the follicles is monitored using vaginal ultra sound scans and blood estradiol levels. 3. The third step is that of egg collection ( egg retrieval) , where he collects the eggs from your mature follicles, and sends them to the embryologist in the IVF lab, where they are placed in culture medium. 4. Then comes fertilization, where either using IVF or ICSI, the embryologist adds sperm to the egg. 5. Then is the process of embryo culture, where the embryos are grown in the IVF laboratory in the incubator, so they divide and grow , till they form blastocysts. 6. This is followed by embryo transfer, where the embryos are put back in the uterus with the hope that they will implant. 7. The final step is that of cryopreservation (freezing for storage) where the extra embryos can be frozen in liquid nitrogen , so that they can be used for future attempts. This ensures nothing is wasted or thrown away.

What is IVF process?
IVF (In Vitro Fertilization) is a process where eggs are collected from the ovaries and fertilized with sperm in a laboratory. The resulting embryos are then transferred into the uterus to establish a pregnancy. It helps couples who have difficulty conceiving naturally. For more details, you can read this article: https://www.drmalpani.com/knowledge-center/ivf/ivf-treatment-plan/

I want to try an experiment to help Indian students to learn better.I want to give a grant of Rs 1 lakh each , with no strings attached, to ten entrepreneurs who have a missionary zeal to improve the education provided to Indian children.You might say that Rs 1 lakh is peanuts , but I am looking for people who understand that being frugal is the way to go .If you are smart , you can make Rs 1 lakh go a long way in India.I don't want founders who solve problems by throwing money at it !And if you do a good job , then there is more dry powder where that money came from !I am looking for people who have focus ; who have a can-do attitude ; who treat constraints as a spur to creativity; who understand how to get the biggest bang for their buck; and who want to grow this frugally and organically , so that it becomes scale-able and sustainable , and is not dependent on funding by investors with deep pockets. I suggest checking our investment thesis.context: WEBC11 03/12/2016 10:46:47 Page 128 128 THE ART OF STARTUP FUNDRAISING SixKeyQuestions toAskPotential Investors Dig in and get a better feel for the real spirit and value of your potential investors quickly by knowing what questions to ask. 1. What additional expertise can this investor bring to the table? 2. Who can this investor introduce and connect me to? 3. How solvent and \ufb02ush is this investor? 4. Is this investor looking to create shared success, or just take all they can? 5. Do we share the same values and level of integrity?

Before you say 'I do' to an investor Ask around, even ask the investor themselves - what can you bring to the table that is not cash? Not in a demanding manner, but as a matter of fact - as an entrepreneur, you deserve to know this. The key is not to select the investor that gives the best answer, it is to select someone who is honest and trustworthy. You want to be on the same page regarding the contribution of people that have the privilege of sitting on your cap table.Some softer guidelinesToo many cooks will spoil the brothThe fewer investors, the better. If investors come in as a group, please ensure you are dealing with just one nominee. It is very easy to run around like a headless chicken when there are multiple investors seeking your bandwidth in diverse and opposite directions. This is the shortest route to a catastrophe.Familiarity is your best betVenture capitalists that have been former entrepreneurs will always be the better investor than a finance guy! Not only will you find more empathy from them, but they will also be more humble than a number-crunching excel gymnast that has not been in the trenches before!Fund vs IndividualThis is a personal choice. An individual investor or family office will be far more flexible and have a longer horizon than a VC fund. However, a VC fund "should" ideally be able to offer far more support.Closing commentsPeople are investing to get a return. Do expect hard negotiation on entry valuations, and rights. But in all the cold hard numbers and facts, please remember to look for 'heart'. If the investor only desires to earn money from this engagement without the urge to create a long-lasting business, walk away. Entrepreneurship, like marriage, is a long and difficult journey with many ups and downs.Find someone you also want to wake up to, not just someone you want to go to bed with.

What is the Cost for IVF?
A complete IVF cycle at our clinic costs about Rs 3,00,000 - and this is all-inclusive for all medical procedures. Medicines would cost about Rs  145000 more.

 Included services in our IVF cost:

    Ovarian stimulation monitoring

    Anesthesia for egg retrieval

    Egg retrieval procedure

    Fertilization and culture of the eggs

   All physician, IVF lab, and facility fees associated with in vitro fertilization

There is NO extra cost for doing ICSI or a blastocyst transfer !

Excluded services - not included in our IVF costs:

    Pre-IVF screening tests 

   Blood tests ( such as E2 levels)

    Embryo or sperm freezing or storage - these are optional services

The cost for freezing and storing embryos is Rs 70000 per year

The cost for thawing and transferring them is Rs 70000

We do NOT charge for followup consultations; or for reviewing test results.

https://www.drmalpani.com/knowledge-center/articles/cost-of-ivf
The total cost to have a baby ( your final goal !)  will depend upon the number of cycles required to achieve success.

What is the Cost for IVF?
The average cost of a regular IVF cycle with a fresh blastocyst transfer at Malpani Infertility Clinic is approximately Rs 2 to 4 lakhs (depending on the cost of injections and if you have embryos to freeze). We don't charge extra for doing ICSI and culturing to blastocyst stage For a specific quotation based on your individual needs, please email [info@drmalpani.com](mailto:info@drmalpani.com) and they will be happy to assist you. [Read More](https://www.drmalpani.com/knowledge-center/articles/cost-of-ivf-old)

What is the Cost for IVF?
The cost of IVF can vary depending on several factors, including the location of the clinic, the specific treatments and procedures involved, any additional services or medications required, and the individual needs of the patient. It's best to consult with your chosen clinic for a detailed breakdown of costs. In our clinic, the charges vary from Rs 2 lakhs to 3 lakhs per cycle for the medical treatment expenses. Injections and additional procedures, such as embryo freezing, cost extra. Please email us at drmalpani@drmalpani.com so we can share the exact pricing structure with you

Can you provide a general estimate of the cost range for IVF at your clinic?
The general cost for a complete IVF cycle at our clinic is between Rs 3 lakhs - Rs 5 lakhs Additional costs may include consultation fees (US $20, or around Rs. 1500) and the cost of pre-IVF tests and medications (approximately US $1000, or around Rs. 85,000).

What is the Cost for IVF?
The cost of an IVF procedure can vary depending on various factors. At Dr. Malpani's IVF clinic, the average cost of a regular IVF cycle is approximately Rs 2 to 4 lakhs. This includes clinical fees, consultation, ultrasound monitoring, medication costs, blood tests, pre-IVF tests, operation theater costs, vaginal egg collection, embryo transfer, cyst aspiration, PESA/TESE (surgical sperm retrieval), IVF laboratory costs (ICSI), embryo freezing and thawing, and embryo storage. Please note that this is an all-inclusive package cost and may vary based on individual requirements. [Read More](https://www.drmalpani.com/knowledge-center/articles/cost-of-ivf-treatment-in-india)

What is the Cost for IVF?
The cost of IVF at Dr. Malpani's clinic is approximately Rs 2 to 4 lakhs, depending on the specific treatment required and if you have embryos to freeze. This includes all medical procedures, scans, egg pickup, and embryo culture to Day 5 (blastocyst). Additional costs include consultation fees and pre-IVF tests. Embryo freezing and storage are extra. Medication costs can vary but are typically around Rs 100000 more for one complete cycle.

Before starting an IVF cycle, we require.context: What are pre screening tests? Pre-IVF screening tests are done before starting your IVF cycle to optimise your IVF treatment protocol. I need the results of ALL the following simple medical tests before starting an IVF cycle. 1. semen analysis for your husband ( to check his sperm count and motility); 2. blood tests for you for the following reproductive hormones - FSH ( follicle-stimulating hormone), LH ( luteinising hormone), PRL ( prolactin), AMH ( anti-Mullerian hormone) and TSH ( thyroid stimulating hormone) on Day 3 of your cycle, ( to check the quality of your eggs). 3. A vaginal ultrasound scan on Day 2 or 3 and again on Day 10 or 11 which should check for the following. a. ovarian volume b. antral follicle count c. uterus morphology d. endometrial thickness and texture Please find a digital ultrasound scanner for your scan. They will burn the images as a jpeg file on a CD or flash drive. I want the raw images as jpeg files please - not scanned in copies of the paper printout - too much loss of resolution with this! Please send me the ALL the detailed test results and medical reports. You can scan them in as a single Word file and email them to me. If the tests have been done in the past one year, there is no need to repeat them. If there is a problem, then we can treat it prior to starting IVF!

Tests prior to IVF If you need IVF treatment in order to get pregnant, we will need to do certain tests to determine:If we can do IVF for youWhat kind of IVF treatment would be best for you ( IVF ? ICSI ? ZIFT ? donor eggs ?)What your chances of success will beMany clinics order a huge battery of tests routinely before starting IVF treatment. They use a mindless checklist approach - which can drain quite a bit of blood - and money ! Many of these tests are pointless, because they provide little useful information. However, this seems to be the norm, especially in large IVF centers ( which are run as mills and employ a huge number of doctors); as well as in the US, where testing is often done for non-medical reasons.We prefer taking a simplified, patient-friendly approach by focusing on what is medially important. We customize this testing, depending upon the patient. In order to do IVF, remember that we only need to check the following: eggs; sperm; uterus and tubes.We usually do just the following simple medical tests before starting an IVF cycle. If the tests have been done in the past one year, there is no need to repeat them.For the husband, all we need is a simple semen analysis ( www.drmalpani.com/semen-analysis.htm) , to check sperm count , motility and morphology.a. If it's normal, then we plan to do IVF.b. If it's abnormal, then we plan to do ICSI. If there is an element of doubt ( for example, if the counts vary a lot), then ICSI is a safer option, as fertilization is guaranteedc. If it's zero, then we need to consider sperm retrieval through TESE or PESAThe wife needs more extensive testing.1. blood tests for the following reproductive hormones : FSH ( follicle-stimulating hormone),LH ( luteinising hormone),PRL ( prolactin) and TSH ( thyroid stimulating hormone) on Day 3 of the cycle, ( to check the quality of the eggs). This needs to be done from a reliable lab such as Specialty Ranbaxy ( www.srl.in). If these tests are normal, then the standard superovulation regimen can be followed . However, if there is a problem, then this will need to be corrected.a. A high prolactin ( www.drmalpani.com/prolactin.htm) can be corrected by treatment with bromocriptine or cabergolineb. Abnormal thyroid levels ( www.drmalpani.com/thyroid.htm) can be treated with medications

The IVF process involves helping your ov.context:
What is the IVF process?
The IVF process involves helping your ovaries growmore eggs ( superovulation) , retrieving them through a minor surgical procedure ( egg retrieval) , fertilizing them with sperm in a lab dish and then transferring one ( or more) embryo backs into the uterus. It takes about 2- 3 weeks to complete an IVF cycle. For further information on this topic please visit
https://www.drmalpani.com/knowledge-center/ivf/ivf-treatment-plan

The 7 steps of IVF IVF seems to be an extremely complicated procedure, and sometimes IVF doctors take perverse pleasure in mystifying it, because they like showing off their expertise. This is why IVF patients are often completely confused about what to expect. Actually , it's very straightforward and logical, and if you understand this simple framework , you will be able to make sure your doctor's doing the right stuff for you. Remember that all we are doing in an IVF cycle is replicating what should have happened normally in the fallopian tubes - the only difference is that we are doing this in the test tube ! 1. First is the pre-IVF testing, or the workup. These are simple tests, to make sure whether IVF is the right treatment for you; and what kind of IVF you require ( for example, if this should be IVF or ICSI).(a). semen analysis for your husband ( to check his sperm count and motility); (b) blood tests for you for the following reproductive hormones - FSH ( follicle-stimulating hormone),LH ( luteinising hormone),PRL ( prolactin) , AMH ( anti-Mullerian hormone) and TSH ( thyroid stimulating hormone) on Day 3 of your cycle, ( to check the quality of your eggs). (c) A vaginal ultrasound scan on Day 10 or 11 which should check for a. ovarian volume; b. antral follicle count; c. uterus morphology; d. endometrial thickness and texture, to confirm your uterus is normal. If there is a problem, then this can be treated prior to starting IVF! 2. Second is the stage of superovulation , where the doctor gives you hormonal injections in order to help you to grow lots of eggs. The growth of the follicles is monitored using vaginal ultra sound scans and blood estradiol levels. 3. The third step is that of egg collection ( egg retrieval) , where he collects the eggs from your mature follicles, and sends them to the embryologist in the IVF lab, where they are placed in culture medium. 4. Then comes fertilization, where either using IVF or ICSI, the embryologist adds sperm to the egg. 5. Then is the process of embryo culture, where the embryos are grown in the IVF laboratory in the incubator, so they divide and grow , till they form blastocysts. 6. This is followed by embryo transfer, where the embryos are put back in the uterus with the hope that they will implant. 7. The final step is that of cryopreservation (freezing for storage) where the extra embryos can be frozen in liquid nitrogen , so that they can be used for future attempts. This ensures nothing is wasted or thrown away.

What is IVF process?
IVF (In Vitro Fertilization) is a process where eggs are collected from the ovaries and fertilized with sperm in a laboratory. The resulting embryos are then transferred into the uterus to establish a pregnancy. It helps couples who have difficulty conceiving naturally. For more details, you can read this article: https://www.drmalpani.com/knowledge-center/ivf/ivf-treatment-plan/
